, keeping a slight distance from the Gulf of Mexico.  A short trip along the highway can reveal scenes and character that you can't get along the interstate.  Expect to see skyscrapers and shacks, sprawl and space, and everything in between - and this is only a small slice of what there is to see in Texas.

This itinerary is written for a three-day weekend trip, Friday through Sunday, especially about the second Saturday in June.  Several of the listed attractions are only available about that time.  Of course, by picking only a few of the listed items, a traveller can follow the full route in under a day.

While some locations are fairly remote, you'll never be too far from civilization.  You'll need to use a private car (there are plenty of rental locations at either endpoint), so just make sure to stop for gas when you near a quarter tank.  Aside from a basic road safety kit, you'll be able to meet any need that comes up with roadside resources.  The most remote place on SH-35 is less so than some places on
If you aren't already in the
area, it's closer to fly into Houston Hobby Airport (HOU) - it borders SH-35.
While the "headwaters" of SH-35 are in Mason Park, on Bray's Bayou, safety, sprawl, standards, and one-way streets limit the practical starting point to SH-35 (Telephone Rd.) at I-45 (Gulf Freeway).

Begin by heading south on SH-35 (here known as Telephone Rd.) from I-45.  You'll quickly pass IH-610 and through Houston's Golfcrest neighborhood.  This area was considered posh in the 1920s, but has since fallen and is beginning to gentrify.  While there is little of specific historical merit along the road, the sights are worth seeing.

After you pass Hobby Airport and the urbanization fades, you'll pass pastures and feed stores before you even reach BW-8 (the Beltway).  You will notice an abrupt rising of buildings again as you enter

value: directions=The big open space with lots of airplanes flying real low
content=Home of Southwest Airlines, the second largest airport in Houston.
directions=The towering white structure of adjacent cylinders on the right
content=Now-defunct facility where rice was dried and hulled, a standing homage to one of the three staple crops of the area (the other two being sugar and cotton).

If you started in the morning, you might already be ready for something to eat.  Among many great places to breakfast are the
, if you have time to sit down and enjoy yourself, or

value: directions=On the right, at Broadway St.
content=Homestyle country cookin' & the best pies in Pearland.
directions=On the left, after Broadway St.
content=Generic fast food, but if you must stop here, try a vanilla Dr. Pepper.

Take 521 after Angelton, cross the Brazos.

value: content=One of Texas' most important rivers, lending its name one of the first state capitols,
content=Depression-era school building, recovered and rebuilt into a community center.  Houses some museum exhibits, classrooms, and community theater.
content=Housed in the 1897 Brazoria County Courthouse, there are wonderful exhibits from across the county.
content=West Columbia was the first capitol of the Republic of Texas.  See related exhibits at this branch of the museum.
directions=Just before you reach West Columbia, take FM-2852 north (right) to Park Road 51.
content=The historic plantation site of the Hogg family.  Activities include an interpretive tour, picnicking, walking, and seasonal festivals.
content=Tours are not currently available, and it's a ways off SH-35, but how many times do you get to see an operating nuclear plant?
hours=Gates open all hours, Visitor center open 9-6
content=See a vast number of birds and variety of wildlife in nature.  Bring sunscreen and bug spray!
directions=Take SH-60 south (left), turn west (right) on FM-2668, go two miles, turn right on Riverside Park Road
content=Hundred acre park on the Colorado River.

If you didn't catch lunch in Brazoria, there's a couple more places not far down the road in Old Ocean.

value: content=Local barbecue, makes a great lunch.

Bay City has several decent places too.

.  Stay on Business 35 (1st St., then Main St., then follow it right).  If you've been visiting most of the listed attractions, it will probably be coming up on dinner time.  Take a couple of hours for a good meal, walk along the water, and look around at some of the history.

value: content=Housed in the R. J. Hill building,

content="The Palace of Palacios", originally the Bay View Hotel, has been a fixture of the community for nearly a hundred years. Check in to see its history, including movie stars, war heroes, and the pier.
content=Palacios is known as the "Shrimp Capital of Texas," see the fleet that gives this reputation.
content=Founded in 1906 as the "Baptist Young Peoples Union," this camp is still in operation.

content=The restaurant entrance is on the side, if you come in the front you'll find the hotel lobby.  While you'll pass Blessing before you get to Palacios, the breakfast might be worth the fifteen minute backtrack.
content=Local seafood and more.  They'll probably have live music on Thursdays and Fridays, and most Saturdays, out back in the barn.
content=Ideal place for meetings, weddings, and banquets. Within walking distance to food, grocery, and public transit including transit across the bay to Palo Alto and Menlo Park.
content=While there are several places to get a room in town, you won't get a better local feel than the Luther.
content=A restored hotel.  It's about fifteen minutes back North on SH-35.  The front door is the hotel lobby.
content=Waterfront rooms in a hundred year old home.
content=Wireless internet access, great breezes.  Wine and music out back on Friday nights.
content=Upscale, restored 1910 waterfront home, bay views, luxury rooms, wireless Internet, opened 2008.

Get up, grab breakfast (you might consider heading back up north to Blessing to eat at the Hotel), and get on the road.  The
was moved from Palacios to Port Lavaca several years ago for preservation.  It's appropriate that you'll pass right by it.

is well worth the detour, though getting there can be an adventure.  Follow SH-35 south again.  FM-185 makes a staggered cross of SH-35 a few miles down the road.  Take FM-185 south (left).  You'll pass through Long Mott (if you even notice it), and find yourself deep in the middle of nowhere.  Press on!  You'll eventually pass The Captain's Quarters on the left, and come up Main St.  Take it south (right) to reach the water.

If you happen to come into town on the weekend of the second Saturday in June, you're in for a treat.
is held on Friday and Saturday night, and the

finishers begin to come in Sunday evening.  Both of these events are at the pavilion in Bayfront Park.  If you stay for the festivities, you might need to spend a second night on the road.  Be aware that lodgings in Seadrift on that weekend are usually completely booked a year in advance, and plan accordingly.

You might otherwise consider chartering a fishing trip on the bay.

value: content=Explore Seadrift's Bayfront Park, go fishing, or just sit under the pavilion in the breeze.
content=Scattered about town, though several are in Bayfront Park.
price=free admission and parking, $25/person entry for events
content=Seadrift's annual festival commemorating one o the biggest industries of the area.  8–9 June 2007.
content=Billed as the world's toughest boat race, it finishes at the flagpole in Seadrift.  Boats will roll in from 10 to 12 June 2007
content=Great spot for a local lunch.  The chicken fried steak comes recommended, along with the seafood.
content=Mexican fare, breakfast served all day.
content=A local inn on the bay.  All rooms tend to be booked a year in advance on the weekend of the second Saturday in June (Shrimpfest and Water Safari weekend), so call ahead.
directions=On 185 just north of Main St.
content=All rooms tend to be booked a year in advance on the weekend of the second saturday in June (Shrimpfest and Water Safari weekend), so call ahead.

Get out of Seadrift in the morning (unless you dally and get some morning fishing in).  Take FM-185 north (left) to SH-35, Then SH-35 south (right) through Tivoli (don't blink, you might miss it!) to Rockport.

began as a cattle packing town about the time of the civil war, but became a fishing village in the 1920s.  Its primary industries now are fishing (and shrimping) and tourism (and recreation).  You'll be able to rent a jetski or sailboat, swim, and explore the town.

value: content=You'll cross this river just before Tivoli.  You can hop out and look at the river, but beware of gators!

directions=About one mile past Tivoli, take FM-239 south (left) to Austwell.  FM-239 becomes FM-774 at the curve.  Take a right at the stop sign, a right at the end of the street, left on FM-2040, and enter the gate six miles after.
hours=Refuge open during daylight, Visitor center open 8:30-4:30 every day except Thanksgiving and Christmas
content=See a huge variety of wildlife, including the Texas Whooping Cranes (at least in the early spring).
content=If you come through Rockport at the right time (5–7 October in 2007), you'll catch the Seafair.  There's a whole mess of food, dancing, boat races of all sorts, and even a crab race.
price=$4/day or $10/year parking permit, admission is free
content=These beaches have a reputation for being clean and safe.
address=201 S. Fulton Beach Rd., Fulton

Follow SH-35 South one last time.  It will take you to straight to
(which, despite being Latin for "body", is regularly used as the city's nickname).

value: address=2710 N. Shoreline Blvd., Corpus Christi
hours=9-6 daily, closed Thanksgiving and Christmas
content=See water-related exhibits and creatures.  You can even work with a dolphin trainer if you contact them ahead of time (and spend a lot of money).
directions=The huge ship in the bay!
hours=9-5 Winter, 9-6 Summer, daily except Thanksgiving and Christmas
content=WWII aircraft carrier become museum.  See naval life, the ship, and aircraft complement.
content=Minor league baseball team play during the season. They are the AA affiliate of the Houston Astros.
content=Gulf seafood fresh daily. Nice place to eat in the marina area of CC. Kind of loud.

You might need to catch up on sleep after seeing the sights in town.

value: address=300 North Shoreline Blvd., Corpus Christi

content=This 12-story tower on the marina is out-of-the-ordinary for the Best Western chain. Nice views up and down the coast from most rooms, easy access to CC downtown. Free breakfast in roof restaurant.
name=Omni Corpus Christi Hotel Bayfront Tower
address=900 North Shoreline Blvd., Corpus Christi

content=Located in Corpus Christi's downtown Marina District. The AAA Four-Diamond hotel offers sweeping views of the Corpus Christi Bay, award-winning dining at the Republic of Texas Bar and Grill and complimentary high speed wireless Internet access.
name=Omni Corpus Christi Hotel Marina Tower
address=707 North Shoreline Blvd., Corpus Christi

content= Located in Corpus Christi's downtown Marina District. This luxurious hotel is the perfect location for a vacation getaway. The hotel is ideally located near the Texas State Aquarium, the USS Lexington and offers easy access to deep sea fishing, sailing and jet skiing.
content=Featuring long term lodging and spa rooms.

content= Right on the beach, with a breath-taking view of the bay and the city. Tennis courts, a swimming pool. Close to downtown and the marina,  next to the South Texas Aquarium and the Lexington Aircraft Carrier. One-, two-, and three-bedroom condos for a lease of at least three months.

You can fly out of the airport, or take I-35 north to
.  Or go back north on SH-35 and see what you missed the first time.
